instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4: What is PM_SLP_S4? This is a typo of PM_SLP_S4_L When you see PM_SLP_S4, assume they meant to type PM_SLP_S4_L.
definitions.D7012: What is D7012? Diode between ground and gate of Q7010 on 2013-2015 year model macbook airs, necessary for Q7010 to allow PPDCIN_G3H to flow through to PP3V42_G3H power supply input. When this diode dies or corrodes, PP3V42_G3H input will not have any voltage, and chargers will not turn on. This can often be the problem if a system only works with a knockoff charger/bench power supply. .
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS? This is PPBUS_G3H after passing through a current sense resistor that splits it off from the rest of PPBUS_G3H. The purpose of this is so that we can measure how much current is flowing to this part of the machine..
definitions.PP5V_S4_RS3: What is PP5V_S4_RS3? This is a typo of PP5V_S4RSE When you see PP5V_S4_RS3, assume they meant to type PP5V_S4RSE.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> 0.86v
threads.message:
Hey guys, looking for a hint or two on how or whether or not to even proceed with this one. Thanks in advance!


No LD visible upon receipt.

<DIODE>D7012</DIODE> was knocked off. replaced and restored <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> green/orange light.

Began checking rails and of course everything is present up to <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4_RS3</SIGNAL> whose enable signal at pin 4 of <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> is sitting at .86v which is what <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is reading "up stream" and across the board. checked p/u resistors and any along the path of <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>, they are within spec. What sort of scenario's could cause this odd reading?

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>            .86v stable (is this a pch middle finger held high?)


<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>                                             8.6
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISN</SIGNAL>             8.6
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL>                   8.6 
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>                                            3.45
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>                                           3.3
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>                                                  5

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>                                                   3.3

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> 0.86v
threads.message: Check the usual <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>/50, <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> including traces and termination resistors to data lines, JTAG connector.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> 0.86v
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R6114</RESISTOR> was missing. <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> showed signs of someone else's work and looked untrustworthy so i replaced it along with y1905. I couldn't find the exact clock chip on any donors but plenty with the same prefix which I assumed to be acceptable substitute? termination traces beep.

Looking through the pch power management inputs that appear to be required for <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> I found...

<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> never comes higher than 1.05v. P/U's and other res's on the line are within spec.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> 0.86v
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> should be high of course. Probably crap under SMC if the pull up resistor on this line is ok and has 3V on it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> 0.86v
threads.message:
Hey hey,

Finally got back to this one. Pulled and re balled the smc, same behavior as stated above unfortunately. What are possible causes for pm_slp_$<SIGNAL>4_L</SIGNAL> to read 0.8v? I read a reply that Louis posted on a similar situation (1v) where he stated that 1v is not a "valid" reading. Essentially should be all or nothing is what I interpreted?

<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_1</SIGNAL> is still hanging at 1.05v.


Thanks in advance for any input you guys might have.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> 0.86v
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> hanging at 1V would certainly cause this board to never power on. Check the pull up resistor <RESISTOR>R1405</RESISTOR> and voltage there. If there is 3V there and <RESISTOR>R1405</RESISTOR> is ok then it is either a dead SMC or a dead CPU.
Rip out <RESISTOR>R1802</RESISTOR> to make sure the pull down is not coming from there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> 0.86v
threads.message:
Thanks for the clues. Followed your leads and I'm ashamed to reply that this is one is a clear-cut case of CPUicide. 

Lastly... Are brown/motley-crue-looking-inductors indicative of anything or is that an eventual normal life cycle presence & presentation?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> 0.86v
threads.message: No idea, I would need to see it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> 0.86v
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> 0.86v
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> 0.86v
threads.message:
Thanks for that.

I have nothing further for this thread, looks like a "solved" fail candidate.
